results.title: Humphrey in the snow
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Here’s Humphrey”.
Join Humphrey on his first visit to the snow where he learns to ski, goes for a ride on a skiddoo, makes a model reindeer with Jodie and plays with snowballs. Humphrey in the snow will delight young children as it is a program filled with fun, games and excitement.

results.title: Human rights video kit. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Education Department of Western Australia and Keith Saggers
results.brief_description: Highlights the problems associated with the protection of basic human rights as experienced trough the work of Ammesty International and similar organizations. Part 1 Dramatizes what it would be like to be an adolescent whose human rights were completely removed. Part 2 Provides a case history of a person detained without reason for helping student dissenters.

results.title: Human reproduction. - [2nd. ed.]
results.brief_description: A very clear exposition of human reproduction mainly by the use of animated diagrams showing the male and female reproductive organs, the menstrual cycle, fertilisation and growth of a fetus over the nine months of pregnancy.

results.brief_description: Human Remains reviews the eccentricities of the 20th century’s most reviled dictators (Hitler, Stalin, Mao, Franco, Mussolini).

results.title: Human relations in Japan
results.brief_description: Following a typical middle class Japanese man and his family, this is an account of the importance of human relations in Japanese culture which stems from strong familial traditions and in turn effects the wider corporate and social environment. It discusses relevant Japanese traditions and terms, and uses animated diagrams to illustrate concepts.

results.title: Human nature and organizational realities (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: BNA Communications, Quest Productions, Howard Enders and William C. Jersey
results.brief_description: Discusses Chris Argyris’ theory that worker apathy is not due to laziness but rather a healthy reaction to an unhealthy environment created by common management policies. The typical organisation confines most of its employees to roles that provide little opportunity for responsibility, self reliance or independence. Explains how executive interpersonal relations can be improved.

results.title: Human nature (2001)
results.creator_credit: Studio Canal, Fineline Features, Anthony Bregman, Ted Hope, Spike Jonze, Charlie Kaufman and Michel Gondry
results.brief_description: Feature film debut for video filmmaker Michel Gondry and follow-up for writer Charlie Kaufman of “Being John Malkovich” fame. A quirky love triangle about dysfunctional people all wanting acceptance, or is it just sex they are after? Lila (Patricia Arquette) is covered in body hair and loves the solitary life of the wild-outdoors but her sexual needs take her to the city. After some intensive hair removal by an electrolysis expert (Rosie Perez), Lila finds love with scientist Nathan (Tim Robbins) who experiments on mice, teaching them table manners. Together they find a wild man (Rhys Ifans) who was raised by apes, whom Nathan and his lusty French assistant (Miranda Otto) name “Puff”. After Nathan’s taming and re-training of Puff, Lila wants to free Puff from the laboratory allowing him return to his true nature.

results.title: Human Nature
results.creator_credit: John Bassett and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Planet for the Taking”.
Host, David Suzuki introduces this program with an update on the global environmental crises. Filmed in Botswana, Tanzania, Kenya and the U.S.A, human nature is an exploration of the origins of the human species and the biological inheritance we share with other life forms.

group_siblings.title: The Runaway Brain

results.title: Human motions
results.brief_description: Around 1987, Waliczky used an ATARI 520 ST to make Human Motions (or, Computer Mobiles) his first-ever animations. In these first seven works, Waliczky explored the possibility offered by the ATARI computer of storing and endlessly repeating a one to four seconds long animated sequence. The seven computer animated sequences are: “WHEEL”, “LOVE TRIANGLE”, CENTRAL SHUTTER”, “BALANCE”, WATERBIRD”, CRYING WOMAN”, “EYE”. The COMPUTER MOBILES address a number of major artistic and technical questions which are characteristic of Waliczky’s oeuvre and crop up repeatedly in subsequent works. Among these issues is the principle of colour animation, i.e., the use of changes in colour to create an impression of movement, as in the two mobiles WATERBIRD and CRYING WOMAN. In BALANCE, one of the most attractive works in the COMPUTER MOBILES series, Waliczky arranged the digitized photographs of a man and a woman into an endless vertical composition. The two figures, captured in acrobatic poses, seem to push and pull one another to and fro, as if engaged in a circus performance watched by the camera as it slowly pans upwards.
